The Smith-Waterman algorithm is a dynamic programming algorithm that is used for the alignment of two sequences. The execution time (complexity) of the Smith-Waterman algorithm depends on several factors, including the length of the two sequences, the length of the alignment window, and the parameters used in the algorithm.
In general, the execution time of the Smith-Waterman algorithm increases exponentially with the length of the sequences and the alignment window. This is because the algorithm involves a large number of comparisons between the two sequences, and these comparisons need to be performed for each position in the alignment window.
The Smith-Waterman algorithm has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2 * m * W), where n is the length of the first sequence, m is the length of the second sequence, and W is the length of the alignment window. This means that the execution time of the algorithm will increase quadratically with the length of the sequences and the alignment window.
However, in practice, the execution time of the Smith-Waterman algorithm is often much faster than this worst-case time complexity, due to the use of various optimizations and heuristics. These optimizations and heuristics can reduce the number of comparisons that need to be performed, and can therefore reduce the execution time of the algorithm.
Overall, the execution time of the Smith-Waterman algorithm depends on a wide range of factors, and can vary significantly depending on the specific circumstances of each alignment problem.
